components.text: In this tutorial, you will learn how to deploy your own version of this website. This tutorial will teach you how to deploy using Heroku, which is a very straight-forward service, very easy to use and FREE! You will also use GitHub, to download the website to your account and to upload the website to Heroku.
This tutorial will only talk about deploying with Heroku. If you want to deploy your website on a local server, check the Github description page for the website linked below.

This tutorial will also teach you how to use the various tools available on the website to edit its content. You can use the admin features to create your own version of content, embed links, images, videos and all sorts of components with minimal effort.

list_elements.text: In this chapter, we will simply create a Heroku and a Github account. These tools will be needed in order to download the website to your Github account and upload it to Heroku, which is a cloud server that will make your website available for other users to see for FREE!

components.text: First, you will need a Github account. Go to their website(linked in the name) and create an account. This is a simple process resembling all other sign-up forms you have probably used before.
Once you have created the account, you should login. Your landing page will look something like this.
You can read the guide for a bit to understand what github does, but for the purpose of this tutorial, it is not necessary.
We will do the same with Heroku. Create an account and then log in.
The landing page will look something like this.
You can click the 'New' Button and then 'Create New App'. This will prompt you to the second screen which looks like this.
The name you choose will be the name of you website. For example, if you choose test-server-2018, then the name of your website will be https://test-server-2018.herokuapp.com

Try to have your Github and Heroku accounts set up. In Heroku, you can also create your new app at this point and name it however you want.
These are necessities in order to continue to the next chapter.
In this chapter, you will do all the necessary work to upload and start your website on your heroku server.

list_elements.text: Learn how to fork a repository on Github.
Learn how to link your github repository to your heroku app.
Learn how to deploy your website using heroku.

components.text: In github, every user can have repositories. These can be private and public. A repository is a collection of files, that is stored on the cloud. Github also comes with a version control system, meaning that the state of your files is saved between changes. This means that you can see previous versions of your files after you have made changes. In our context, this can be useful if you have made mistakes when editing the content of the website and want to revert back to a previous state.

This website is available in the format of a github repository. You can find it here. In order to continue at this point, you need to get a copy of this repository into your own github account. In order to do that, there is a process in github called forking a repository.

In order to complete this step, you need to fork a copy of the website template page into your own github account. Simply go to this repository and click the 'Fork' button on the top-right side. This process will take several seconds, and then you will end up with a repository in your github account that has the name 'ifs-template-website'.
You now have a repository in your github account called 'ifs-template-website'. Congratulations!!
The next step is letting our heroku app know where our repository is.

list_elements.text: Go to your dashboard and select the previously created heroku app.
Go to the 'Deploy' tab
Where it says 'Deployment Method', click on Github.
Below that, there is a form with the title 'Search for a repository to connect to'. Start typing the name of your repository, which should be 'ifs-template-website' if you haven't changed the name.
Once you click 'Search', the results will show just below. Click 'Connect' on the search result that pops up.

After you connect the repository to heroku, more options will appear on the screen. You don't have to worry about these. Simply scroll all the way down to the section labelled 'Manual Deploy' and then click the button 'Deploy Branch'.

After you click the button, the repository is copied on the heroku server. This takes some time, but you are provided feedback in the logs below. Once this process is done, another button will pop up , the 'View' button. Clicking this will take you to your new website.

components.text: You have done a lot of work in this chapter, and you now have a brand new website ready and deployed. It is time now to take a look at how to protect its admin features so that you are the only one that can access them. Let's talk about Authentication.

The admin page of this website lets you edit the entire content of the website, and the button to access it is available from the top bar. The admin page has been exposed in such way to make it easier for you and other content creators to access it.

Because it is so exposed, there are a couple of authentication methods available to restrict access to it. If you opt for any of the authentication methods, you can better protect the content of the website.
None of the two authentication methods are mandatory, but it is highly advised to include at least the local authentication.

To learn how to set up github authentication and how to use it.

components.text: The username and password for the admin features are stored in environment variables.
To create these on a local server, there are instructions on the template's github repository.
To do this on Heroku, follow these steps:

list_elements.text: Open your app from your dashboard
Go to the Settings Tab
Click on Reveal Config Vars

You must enter two variables, one for the username, one for the password.
There is a KEY field and a VALUE field and a button ADD.
For the username, enter USERNAME in the key field (must be all caps) and in the value field enter your desired username and click ADD.
For the password, enter PASSWORD in the key field (must be all caps) and in the value field enter your desired password and click ADD.

components.text:
You have now set up some authentication for your website.
Try to access the admin page now and if everything is all right, you should be prompted to enter these variables. 
You now have a secure admin page!

chapters.name: Getting to grips with page structure

components.subtitle: Blocks
components.text: Blocks are the main elements of your data. They encapsulate all chapters and are available in the navigation menu on the left. The blocks in this case are: Introduction, Getting the website running, Authentication etc.
Blocks are made of chapters. Below there is an example of blocks.

components.subtitle: Chapters
components.text: Chapters are the containers inside a block. For example, the chapters for the 'Admin Primer' block are : Introduction, Getting to grips with page structure, Adding and removing elements, etc. See below an example of chapters in the block Admin Primer

components.subtitle: Sections
components.text: Each page is made of several sections. A section starts with a coloured title. Sections also appear on the right side navigation menu for quick navigation. An example of a section can be seen below
It is good practice to give your Blocks, Chapters and Sections very relevant names, as they appear in navigation menus and allow the user to quickly navigate to what they are looking for

components.subtitle: Components
components.text: Everything else is a component. All paragraphs, images, videos, alerts, links are components. When you create a page, it will usually be several sections which contain several components. We will go over components more in a later chapter. An example of some components can be seen below.
The main menu on the left contains all the Blocks and Chapters, while the menu on the right will display all sections on the currently selected Block+Chapter.
Notice that when you select a Block, it will automatically select the first Chapter from it. A block cannot contain anything else besides Chapters.
All Blocks, Chapters and Sections must have a name. Name is optional for components.
When you edit the content, you must always have at least 1 Block with 1 Chapter. The website will not let you delete content if you have less than required.
You can notice many buttons on the admin page. Everything in here is editable, therefore there are many ways you can interact with your blocks, chapters, sections and components.

components.subtitle: The Add Buttons
components.text: There are 4 different Add buttons available. You can add Blocks and Chapters from the menu on the left. You can add Sections to a Page through the Add Section button at the bottom of the page, or the Add New Section button on the right-side menu.
You can add components with the Add Component button. Since components must belong to a Section, every Section comes equipped with this button at the bottom of the Section.

components.subtitle: The Colored Borders
components.text: There are coloured borders displayed for Sections and Components. Sections have a blue border, and Components have a red border. This is so you can easily identify which component and section you are currently editing.
Notice that components(red borders) are encapsulated in sections(blue borders). You must understand this hierarchy before proceeding forward.
Blocks contain chapters, which contain sections, which contain components.

components.subtitle: The Collapse Button
components.text: Sections and Components can get fairly big in size, making it hard to navigate your page. These two elements come equipped with a Collapse button at the beginning. Clicking this will collapse the contents of the element, making the page shorter. It is good practice to collapse Sections that you have finished editing, and only leave the Section you are currently working on uncollapsed.

components.subtitle: Move and Delete Widgets
components.text: Every element has these widgets. It's a group of three buttons that can move the element up or down in the hierarchy, or delete it. You can easily change the order of your elements with these buttons, or delete an element. You will be prompted to accept when you try to delete something. They look something like this:

Chapters are parts of a block. You can see them listed on the left hand side menu. When you click on a block, you see all the chapters inside that block. You can add a new chapter by clicking on the
Add new Chapter
button. The chapter is added in the current active block.
You can change the order of the chapters within a block by using the and buttons. You can delete a chapter by pressing the

Sections are the main elements of a chapter (a page). Sections also appear on the right-side menu for quick navigation (their name is displayed there). You can add a new section by clicking on the
Add new Section
button available on the right-side menu.

You can also add sections from the
Add Section
button avaiable at the bottom of the page.
You can change the order of the sections within a page using the and buttons. You can delete a section by pressing the

Components are everything else on the page. They have a red border. Every section of the page is made of components. There are several types of components, like image, text, video, quote, reference etc. You can add a new component by clicking on the
Add Component
button available at the bottom of every section.
You can change the order of the components within a section using the and buttons. You can delete a component by pressing the
All of these actions are reversible from the Undo Stack
Once you access a chapter (a page), you will see all the elements of the page exposed. Most elements will have this icon on the top-left or next to their name.
Clicking on the icon will open an interface on the right side which lets you edit the corresponding element.

Blocks and chapters only have a name property. There is no button on the navigation menu on the left-hand side, simply because it was obscuring the names too much. To change the name of a block or a chapter, first you must access the chapter page, and at the top of the page you will see the block name with the icon next to it and underneath there is the chapter name with the icon next to it. Accessing the interface for the block or chapter will let you change their name.

Sections are the parts of the page with blue borders. They contain components, but they also have a name property which is mandatory, and a checkbox property for drawing a horizontal line at the end of the section. The icon lets you access the section interface to edit these two properties. It is situated in the top-left corner of the section, which is enclosed in blue borders.
Each component also comes equipped with the icon which is situated in the top-left corner. Just a reminder, components are enclosed in red borders.
Components are more complex, they contain various properties depending on the type. We will not go in-depth here about each component, we will talk about what properties all components share.

When you open the interface for a component, you will see three tabs. The first tab is called Component Basics and here you can edit the subtitle of the component and the checkbox property that draws a horizontal line at the end of the component.
The next tab is called Component Type. Here you can change the type of the component, if you are not happy with the type you chose when you created it.

The last tab is custom, based on what type you selected for the component. It is usually named {{Type}} Options. Here you can edit all the various properties of a specific component type. You can find more information on component types and their properties at this link.
On the far-right side of the page, you can see this button:
Most of your actions while editing are registered in this stack. You can see your previous actions by clicking the button.

Each of these actions gives you a brief description about where the change was made ( which block, chapter, section and component) and also displays an icon to show what type of action was made ( delete, move, add, edit). Each entry has an UNDO button that allows you to revert the state of your document back to how it was before that change.

When you click UNDO, you are reverting back the document to how it was before that change. That means that if you UNDO the 6th element in the stack, you will also lose the changes made in the 5 elements above. Think of this as hitting CTRL + Z on a windows machine. It reverts your previous change, but in order to revert back to the 6th previous change you made, you have to undo the 5 before as well.
